"Due to the inactive lifestyle and stressful lives, many people get lifestyle diseases such as diabetes, high blood pressure, etc. Fit India Movement can encourage people to consume healthy food and maintain physical and mental fitness."

"With high-quality advertising and marketing practices, junk food manufacturers manipulate children to buy their food. This Fit India movement will let children think about the negative consequences of Junk Food. As a result, this exercise will encourage children to consume healthy food."

"Some parents have put too much stress on children to study. They send their children to school or simply leave them to do homework and forget about the importance of leisure time. This movement has the potential to change their minds, and as a result, they can encourage their children to move out and play."

"This movement has the potential to allow more people to embrace traditional Indian martial arts such as Kathi Samu, Musti Yudha, etc., traditional dance forms and healthy Indian snacks. And as a by-product, this can lead to job creation."
"The motivation to maintain fitness should start from childhood. But in India, many schools lack playgrounds. Lack of playgrounds can lead children to turn to inactive lifestyles."

"The Fit India movement must not reach people below the poverty line. In order to maintain a healthy lifestyle, both physical activity and nutritious food are necessary. But in India many people are still malnourished and some people do not have access to clean drinking water. So, without solving the problem of poverty and lack of access to affordable nutritious foods, some of the people in India will not be able to use this movement."

"Some people are already focusing on fitness. We can observe this with the increasing number of fitness startups. But that's a small part of people. In general, many people want to maintain an active lifestyle, but all they need is some encouragement. Thus, this exercise constantly reminds us of fitness goals, as Swachh Bharat reminds us of how important it is to keep our environment clean."

"Since the invention of machines, the value of the workers has declined. They are used to support the machines. This is how work revolves around machines and not people. Workers are forced to work continuously with the machine. "

"People are now dealing with trolling and cyberbullying. To hide behind devices is to give them the courage to harass other people, which they may not do face to face. This is the deterioration of moral values."

"Some companies are developing strategies to use their apps for a longer period of time to keep us addicted to their apps and devices so they can show us ads. And they too can use our data to manipulate our choices for their profit. These strategies make people just goals."

"Industrialization increased working hours. Workers faced inhumane conditions. People cannot continuously work and focus like machines. Quickly forward to today, we have technological equipment to check how many hours we actually work. Some companies want to be connected 24 hours a day through emails and messages. This makes people feel less human."

"Our decision-making skills are also affected, as we now ask search engines to know what is best. We are also dependent on the knowledge base of the Internet in offices to finish the work at hand. This concerns cognitive abilities (thinking, reading, learning, remembering and reason), which is an essential quality of man."

"Many face-to-face communications are also replaced by virtual interactions. Many people now live in virtual houses, that's the smartphone. As the need to talk to each other decreases, the ability to communicate with each other decreases, which is a fundamental quality of living beings."

"We are increasingly dependent on technological devices to lead us. For example, we keep memories on smartphones and google the questions for answers. We outsourcing the activities that intelligence requires to technology. Thinking, remembering and analyzing are essential qualities of man. Too much dependence on technology makes us less human."

"With the help of technologies, people maintain and improve relationships with their friends, family and relatives. Many people also connect to each other to help the needy and to inspire each other. So now we have better tools to build human connections."

"Technology allows us to work from home. This facility helps employers to better understand workers. Many companies now add elements to the work culture with the help of technology to make employees feel important."

"This bill gave the National Investigation Agency (NIA) exclusive powers. NIA may take any person under UAPA into custody without prior authorisation from the government. This is against federalism guaranteed by India's constitution."

"The labelling of organisations as terrorist organisations and the labelling of individuals as terrorists are quite different. When a person is named as a terrorist, it will be confronted with social exclusion and without a basis for existence, even if it has proved the opposite. The consequences will be irreversible. For example, in 2016 alone 67% of the cases ended acquitted, which means that they are probably innocent."

"If someone is booked under UAPA, the burden of proving their innocence is on them. This new change allows the government to seize its possessions. How will they pay for legal expenses to prove their innocence if they are falsely accused?"

"This will provide the central government with more police forces. The purpose of naming individuals as terrorists can be abused. For example, several civilian activists have recently been referred to as Urban Naxals. If someone opposes the government, they will be vulnerable to being framed as terrorists. Because this change made it easier to call someone terrorists."

"There is a growing threat to lone wolf terrorism. Lone wolf terrorists have no connection with terrorist organizations, but they are committing terrorist attacks alone. This new change in the UAPA has the potential to contain single wolf terrorism."

"In order to prevent the violation of human rights, a four-stage test is added. The designation of individuals as terrorists is not started by India. The US, the European Union and China also have this provision."

"Until now, only organizations have been called terrorist organisations, but not individuals. The loophole here are the individuals of the banned organizations that form new organizations and carry out terrorist activities. This bill of amendment to the Law on Illegal Activities (Prevention) allows the government to designate individuals as terrorists, thereby preventing terrorist attacks."
Terrorism must be fought hard in the face of the increasing threat from terrorists. It is therefore necessary to strengthen the UAPA.

"At present, India does not have a well-developed infrastructure to ensure data security. On the other hand, developed countries already have efficient infrastructure. So if we rush towards data localization, it may not be a wise step. Because without efficient infrastructure, the data is vulnerable to cyberattacks. And the risk is high here because it's financial data. But how the laws are made is a great challenge to develop efficient infrastructure at a faster pace."

"The storage of data in India means higher operating costs for payment system operators. Because in other countries they have cheaper alternatives. And even in cross-border transactions, they have to store the data in two places, which increases costs. There is a likelihood that these additional costs will be passed on to consumers."

"Data localization laws lead to the establishment of several data centres on the ground. This will create many jobs and help the country's economy enormously. It will also drive innovation in this area, leading to cost-effective solutions."

"In the investigation of crimes, it will be necessary to access the payment data. If the data is stored abroad, it is very difficult to take permission from this country for access to the data. This leads to delays in the resolution of crimes. If the data is stored here in our country, this problem will be avoided."

India is a large consumer market for many foreign companies. India and other developing countries thus recognise the economic value of the data and the importance of data localisation. With the data localization, domestic companies and the economy of the country will benefit. And we can also ensure the security of the data.

"Data are considered to be new form of wealth'. In general, companies use data to understand the requirements of consumers and also to influence their behaviour. New products can be developed by analysing data to meet the needs of consumers. The data therefore have an economic value. In general, developed countries are taking advantage of this opportunity with their well-developed infrastructure. "

"We are in a globalized world. Currently, the world is running on the free flow of people, goods, services and data. Data localization laws seem to be part of protectionist policies, which poses a threat to the free flow of data."

"The US is opposed to data localization laws. Recently, at the G20 summit, Donald Trump, the President of the United States, spoke against data localization. His attitude is natural because it increases the operating costs of US companies. Bilateral relations between India and the US are important for both countries because we are in the export and import of IT services, professionals and goods etc. It's intertwined. So imposing data localization laws without threatening Indo-US relations is another challenge."
"We can ensure data protection by locating the data."
Data localisation can lead to state surveillance of its citizens.
"Data localisation is important for data sovereignty, which means that citizens' data should belong to their respective governments and not to other countries."

"The law is very clear that RTI is not only concerned with government agencies alone. It is also intended for non-governmental organisations, which are essentially financed and controlled by the government. There are numerous subsidies (including tax exemptions) that political parties enjoy, which essentially finances them by the government."
"Political parties are independent bodies, they do not have to be accountable to the public. They were not through the constitution or an act of parliament."

"According to RTI, wherever public interest exists, these organisations must be transparent and fall under the law. There are now a number of private organizations, whether partially funded or completely; schools, hospitals, etc. which are covered by the RTI Act and not just government organisations."
"There are appropriate provisions in the Income Tax Act and with the Electoral Commission so that people can have all the information they want."

"The RTI Act contains provisions in Section 8, which mentions the concept of competitive interest. Certain exceptions are granted in cases where it can be demonstrated that the dissemination of information may harm the party's competitive advantage. This is not only a problem with the political parties, but also with many governmental and private bodies."

"It is believed that political funding is the source of corruption. Citizens have the right to know where the political parties are from, how they spend these funds and on the basis of their decisions. Crony capitalism is greatly slowed down when political parties are brought under RTI Act."

"According to the IT law, political parties do not have to disclose donations received under INR 20,000. An informal study conducted in 2010 at six major political parties shows that they raised Rs 700 Crore. 95% of the amount was increased by amounts below Rs 20,000. There is a great possibility that the political parties will use this loophole to their advantage."
"Political parties declare certain promises in their manifestos. After the election, citizens have the right to know why the promises made by the political parties have not been fulfilled."

"Political parties are central to the functioning of democracy. Political parties continue to form the government. Government policy is then governed by party ideology. This makes it essential for political parties to fall within the field of RTI."

"If political parties fall under the RTI, this will affect their proper internal functioning. Rivals can use RTI to insult each other. Since the political parties are not directly linked to the public, an RTI would be invalid."

"In the rest of the world, educational institutions see as machines, we expect to become unemployed and get out with work. We do not realize that we need to improve our skills in order to become worthy of employment. This is the reason why more than 80% of engineers are unable to work and the figures for non-engineers are even worse."

"Although we have established institutes at national level over the past 40 years, we have not invested to maintain their standards. High-quality education requires resources. Even the top Indian institutes lack infrastructure, laboratories, resources, etc. And even what is available is only to pass the students in the exam and to sit idle for the rest of the time."
"Today, no problem has a single solution and no new technology is related to a single discipline. We need several contributions from several disciplines, and our institutes have not done so."

"Indian students perform brilliantly when they go to different countries in the field of research. It means that we do not lack talent, we lack infrastructure and a healthy environment for our sharp minds."

"We did not pay our teachers at the level that their colleagues in other countries deserve. The result is that people hesitate to use the idea of teaching as a career. We have also failed to attract successful foreign faculties to our institutes."

"To achieve excellence in everything takes time. Through the degree, students acquire so much knowledge in the relevant field. This makes it easier for employers to train these students for industrial requirements."
"Every skill can be learned and mastered, even if we do not have a degree in this. And programming is no exception."

"Even if someone has an IT degree, he must learn so many things to get into the IT job, because there is a gap between the industrial standards and the skills taught in engineering colleges. Moreover, since technology is constantly evolving, even if someone has prepared for industrial standards in their degree, they must constantly learn new technologies to remain relevant to the labour market. As the learning curve will also be there for IT students, students from non-IT backgrounds can also learn these things and get involved in IT jobs."

"The number of IT jobs is increasing rapidly due to the technological revolution. There will therefore be more jobs in the IT sector. And if the recruits are very strict about the degree, they may miss a large pool of talents who have a non-IT background."

"Now we have so many online course platforms through which we can learn almost every skill from experts. We can also get certificates if we pass the tests. So, as Tim Cook said, a 4-year degree seems old and traditional."

"In many of the Indian engineering colleges, we can easily pass on the subjects, even if we don't have much knowledge in these subjects. This is why many companies are unable to find suitable talents, even if there are so many qualified graduates. The willingness to become an expert in this field is therefore more important than one degree. "
"If a student from a non-IT background has decided to start a career in the IT field, the efforts they put into graduation will go in vain."

"Although the new programming languages replace the old ones, the basic concepts for almost all programming languages are the same. So whoever has a degree in coding has an advantage over the student from a non-IT background."

"People change careers even after working in an area for several years because our interests change.So if someone can do this while he has so many personal responsibilities, it is much easier for youths to learn a new skill. "
"Variable pay definitely increases employee productivity. Powerful people feel well compensated and rewarded for their efforts, while the low performance also feel motivated to improve."

"In variable pay systems, employees feel satisfied and motivated with their work. They believe to be an active part of the organization, the organization recognizes it as part of its growth and appreciates its efforts."
"Variable pay helps maintain valuable employees. This helps to keep good talents for a long time and thus less spending on hiring new talents. This ensures stability for the organization."

" It has been found that it is difficult to keep workers in lean times when they are on variable pay systems. Workers who receive commissions do well when business is good, but they do badly when business is bad. In times of slow business, even top sellers might have trouble getting enough sales to earn a decent living. If the market is slow and contract workers cannot earn enough, they can look for other employment opportunities. In lean times, fixed wages can be more effective to prevent workers from taking advantage of other opportunities."

"Variable pay can lead to unhealthy competition between employees. They become less willing to help each other. Team cooperation can have a negative impact. In the long run, relations between colleagues can become bitter. While employees are able to maintain cordial relations in the office with fixed pay systems."

"The country of origin should be absolutely the most important criterion for deciding who to let in our countries. 160 French people would still be alive if we put the well-being of our own above the people whose countries the Americans have bombed into pieces."
" It's time to be honest! Europeans have the right to self-determination like any other country out there! This is our home and a home for everyone is a home for no one."

"Our continent Europe is in debt and does not have the means to take care of people who have never paid taxes and continue to disregard our laws! We already have enough poor people in Europe and we have to take care of them!"

"I do not agree to deprive people of their right to asylum and their right to live in the EU because they have come illegally. Instead, I would propose to facilitate legal migration. In this way, there would be no need to migrate illegally while risking your life."
The division of refugees is a long-discussed plan. In the end, however, no participating group agreed to these plans. Some countries do not like these people at all.
